data.title: The 30 Most Influential People in Tech
data.meta_description: When I joined the tech community by leading CoFoundersLab, one of the largest networks of entrepreneurs, I spent a large amount of time familiarizing myself with the industry's key influencers and with how startup fundraising works. Now that I have been involved in this space for quite some time, I put together [...]
data.text:
When I joined the tech community by leading CoFoundersLab, one of the largest networks of entrepreneurs, I spent a large amount of time familiarizing myself with the industry's key influencers and with how startup fundraising works.

Now that I have been involved in this space for quite some time, I put together the following list describing in detail who is behind the most inspiring and innovative companies in tech. If you happen to know any of them, you and your company are definitely in good shape. If you are on this list, then congratulations.

Pete Cashmore - Mashable

Cashmore is the founder of Mashable. This blog has been able to establish itself as the go to place to finding trends in the digital world. With millions of unique users reading his publication, Cashmore has a channel to speak his opinion and influence millions around the world.

Sheryl Sandberg - Facebook

Sandberg is the COO of Facebook, the biggest and most well known social network in the world. With over 200 million people using their service on a monthly basis, the company has one of the most important voices in tech. Even though Mark Zuckerberg (Founder & CEO) is the face of the company and without a doubt, a genius, Sandberg is known to be a powerhouse driving the most successful company in Silicon Valley, and arguably in the world.

Tim Cook - Apple

Cook is the CEO of Apple. He is the decision maker in a company that has revolutionized the way humans see and use technology. Cook has filled the seat of one of the biggest visionaries of our time, Steve Jobs. It is still to be determined whether or not he will be able to continue the long-term growth of the company as the successor to a true genius.

John Doerr – Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers

Doerr is a venture capitalist and partner at the firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. He is one of the most respected tech visionaries in the industry. Doerr has directed venture capital funding to some of the most successful technology companies in the world including Compaq, Netscape, Symantec, Sun Microsystems, drugstore.com, Amazon.com, Intuit, Macromedia and Google.

Virginia Rometty - IBM

Rometty is the Chairwoman and CEO of IBM. She is the first woman to ever lead the company. Rometty is someone who has been able to find the way up, as she started working at IBM in 1991 and since then she has skyrocketed to the top. She also serves on the committee of the most powerful schools in the country like Columbia Business School and Northwestern University.

Tim Armstrong – AOL

Armstrong is the CEO and Chairman of AOL. His biggest move was buying The Huffington Post and putting Arianna Huffington in charge of AOL's content. Prior to joining AOL, Armstrong was responsible for Google’s operations in the United States.

Dennis Crowley - Foursquare

Prior to co-founding Foursquare, Crowley co-founded Dodgeball, which was acquired by Google in 2005. With over 20 million unique users, Foursquare is one of the fastest growing companies in the last decade. The application is useful for finding places to go, and seeing tips on what's good or bad when you get to where you're going.

Kevin Ryan – Gilt Groupe

Ryan is the CEO of one of the biggest e-commerce sites in the world. The company has been able to raise over $174 million in funding from some of the most renown venture capitals in the industry. In addition to Gilt Groupe, Ryan has founded several New York-based businesses, including Business Insider, and 10gen/MongoDB, and helped build DoubleClick from 1996 to 2005, first as president and later as CEO.

David Karp – Tumblr

Karp is the founder and CEO of Tumblr. Tumblr is one of the go to places for high graphic blogging. Being part of the top 10 most trafficked websites in the USA and with over 170 million using its service, Karp has definitely put his name out there as one of the most respected individuals in the industry.

Jack Dorsey – Twitter

Dorsey is the creator of Twitter, the biggest micro blogging site on the Internet, with millions of users using its application every month and with over 1.6 billion search queries per day. Dorsey is also the founder and CEO of Square, a mobile payments company that has made a lot of noise during 2012 after raising one of the biggest rounds of funding from the Venture Capital industry.

Larry Page – Google

Page is one of the co-founders and CEO of the most powerful company on the Internet today. As of 2012, his personal wealth is estimated to be $20.3 billion, ranking him #13 on the Forbes 400 list of richest Americans. Page is also an active investor in alternative energy companies, such as Tesla Motors.

Steve Ballmer – Microsoft

Ballmer is the CEO of Microsoft, where he joined in June 1980, becoming Microsoft’s 30th employee. Ballmer was the second person to become a billionaire in U.S. dollars based on stock options received as an employee of a corporation, in which he was neither a founder nor a relative of a founder.

Larry Ellison – Oracle

Ellison is the co-founder and CEO at Oracle Corporation. With an estimated net worth of $41 billion, he is a big decision maker in the tech world. With annual revenues of $37.1 billion last year, Oracle is one of the largest companies developing computer hardware systems and enterprise software products.

Jeff Bezos – Amazon.com

Bezos is the founder and CEO of Amazon.com. He had left his New York City hedge fund job when he learned about the rapid growth in Internet use and drove to Seattle, writing his business plan along the way. He initially set up the company in his garage. Under his guidance, Amazon.com has become the largest retailer on the World Wide Web. In 2011 alone, Amazon's shares have jumped 55% and added $6.5 billion to his net worth.

Michael Dell – Dell

Dell is the founder and CEO of Dell. In 1992 at the age of 27, Dell became the youngest CEO to have his company ranked in Fortune magazine's list of the top 500 corporations. In the first quarter of 2001, Dell reached a world market share of 12.8 percent, passing Compaq to become the world's largest PC maker. He is ranked as the 41st richest person in the Forbes Billionaires list 2012, with an estimated net worth of US$15.9 billion as of March 2012.

Tim O’Reilly - O'Reilly Media

O’Reilly is the founder of O’Reilly Media. O'Reilly Media also created the first web portal, the Global Network Navigator ("GNN") in 1993; it was sold to AOL in 1995, one of the first large transactions of the dot-com bubble. O'Reilly serves on the boards of directors of two companies, CollabNet and MySQL AB, and served on the board of Macromedia until its 2005 merger with Adobe Systems. He also serves on the board of directors for the public-service organization Code for America. In February 2012 he joined the UC Berkeley School of Information Advisory Board.

Pierre Omidyar – eBay

Omydiar is the founder and Chairman of eBay. With a net worth of over $8 billion, he is known as the king of the Internet auctions with the company he founded back in 1995. In addition to his work with eBay, Omydiar and his wife also founded Omydiar Network, a philanthropic investment firm that has already committed more than $270 million to for-profit companies and nonprofit organizations that foster economic advancement and encourage individual participation across multiple investment areas.

Alfred Lin – Sequoia Capital

Lin is currently a partner at Sequoia Capital. He is one of the few Venture Capitalists who really understands how both sides of the table work. Everything he touches turns to gold. Every company he has worked for has been acquired, which include Zappos and LinkExchange totaling an estimated $2 billion. Being a master of operations he knows how to pick winners, one of the main reasons why every single company in the Valley dreams of him sitting on their board of directors.

Marissa Mayer – Yahoo!

Mayer is the President and CEO of Yahoo! Prior to Yahoo!, Mayer was a long-time executive and key spokesperson for Google, where she joined in 1999 as employee number 20 and was the company's first female engineer. When Mayer joined Yahoo! the stock was at $15 per share. Under her leadership, the stock is today valued at $20 per share. This turn around is very impressive, especially bearing in mind that she has held position for less than a year.

Jeff Weiner - Linkedin

Weiner is the CEO of Linkedin, the largest social network for professionals in the world. As of June 2012, LinkedIn reports more than 175 million registered users in more than 200 countries and territories. Before joining LinkedIn, Weiner worked as an Executive-in-Residence for leading Venture Capital firms Accel Partners and Greylock Partners and also served as an executive at Yahoo!

Yishan Wong – Reddit

Wong is the CEO of Reddit. Prior to joining Reddit, Wong was the co-founder of the coworking space Sunfire Offices, and is currently an advisor at Quora. In addition to having President Obama answering questions on his platform, Reddit has become the go to community to check the news and watch videos that are trending. As of June 2012, commentary on the site is particularly active, with some submissions earning hundreds of comments.

Paul Otellini – Intel

Otellini is the current President and CEO at Intel where he joined as an employee in 1974. In addition, Otellini is also on the board of directors of Google. With revenues exceeding $50 billion per year, Intel is one of the largest multinational semiconductor chip maker corporation in the world. On November 19, 2012, Otellini announced his intention to retire in May of 2013.

Scott Cook - Intuit

Cook is the founder of Intuit, an American software company that develops financial, tax preparation software and related services for small businesses, accountants and individuals. Cook has been a director of Intuit since March 1983 and is currently Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Board. Cook also serves on the boards of directors of eBay Inc., and The Procter & Gamble Company.

Meg Whitman – Hewlett-Packard

Whitman is the CEO of Hewlett-Packard, one of the largest providers of products, technologies, software, solutions and services. Prior to Hewlett-Packard, Whitman was the CEO of eBay for 10 years, until early 2008, during which time the online auction company grew from $4 million in revenue to $7.7 billion. Whitman also serves on the boards of P&G and ZipCar.

Marc Benioff – SalesForce.com

Benioff is SalesForce.com's Chairman and CEO. Benioff founded his first company at age 15 to write Atari videogames. He started Salesforce in 1999 after stints at Apple and Oracle, where he was a protégé of Larry Ellison. Benioff recently joined the board of Cisco Systems.

Jack Ma – Alibaba Group and Taobao

Ma is the owner of Taobao and Alibaba Group, two of the most popular sites in China. He is leading a team of over 25,000 employees. Moreover, Ma is a board member of Japan’s SoftBank and China’s Huayi Brothers Media Corporation. He became a trustee of The Nature Conservancy’s China program in 2009 and joined its global board of directors in April 2010. Ma is the first Chinese citizen to serve on The Nature Conservancy’s board.

Vinod Khosla – Khosla Ventures

Khosla was one of the co-founders of Sun Microsystems. In 2004 Khosla formed his own firm, Khosla Ventures, which focused on venture investments in various technology sectors, most notably clean technology. He recently backed nuclear tech company TerraPower, as well as a company making ultra-low-cost fuel cells and another developing combustion engines.

John Chambers – Cisco Systems, Inc.

Chambers is Cisco’s Chairman and CEO, where he joined in 1991. Cisco Systems is one of the largest networking equipment providers in the world. Since January 1995, when Chambers assumed the role of CEO, the company has grown from $1.2 billion in annual revenues to its current run-rate of approximately $40 billion.

Paul Graham – Y Combinator

Graham co-founded Viaweb (which eventually became Yahoo! Store), and Y Combinator. Y Combinator has become the most important accelerator program in the world. The program provides seed money, advice, and connections at two 3-month long programs each year. In exchange, they take an average of about 6% of the company's equity. Some of their better-known funded companies include Scribd, Reddit, Airbnb, Dropbox, Disqus, and Posterous.

Steve Blank – Stanford University
